channel.title: UK developer creates £15 computer for kids
channel.description:
http://www.theinquirer.net/inquirer/news/2068735/uk-developer-creates-gbp15-kids
This is quite a nice idea. Would be great to get them into schools, an inexpensive computer for kids to mess around with. Something that we've missed for a good while.
It is apparently quite capable too, with some interviews with the developer claiming it has 3D graphical capability "well in excess" of the PlayStation 2. I'd love to see the government get behind this with some funding to get it into schools.

item.title: UK developer creates £15 computer for kids
item.dc:creator: @The_Un-Named The Un-Named
item.description:
@The_Un-Named wrote:

RobbieCoding:

That little computer is really stupid. How long would it take to load a webpage? Will it have internet? How much storage? You couldn’t do shit that thing. If you can fit a whole computer into the size of a flash drive then why isn’t my computer clocked at 700 GHz?

allow me to show you a video giving a demonstration of the computer: http://www.youtube.com/watch?v=2Z4m4lnjxkY

Read full topic

item.dc:creator: @Svitkona Svitkona
item.description:
@Svitkona wrote:

[quote=“Niall, post:29, topic:394177”]http://www.amazon.co.uk/Premium-HDMI-Cable-Gold-Metre/dp/B000GDI6FC/ref=sr_1_1?ie=UTF8&qid=1305114452&sr=8-1

that’s what I’ve been using for a few years(VGA pc -> HDMI monitor), I can’t remember if they work both ways but I think the more expensive(£50-70) transcoders are for resolutions you can’t change(i.e., 1080p fixed hdmi to 1024x768 monitor say)

Also, you do realize you can hook a netbook up to any hdmi TV as well, right?

but then you’d be paying £100 for the netbook then £100 more for the tv

On a somewhat related note, anyone remember this?[/quote]
LOL in Egypt we do one book per child

£4.74

that’s what I’ve been using for a few years(VGA pc -> HDMI monitor), I can’t remember if they work both ways but I think the more expensive(£50-70) transcoders are for resolutions you can’t change(i.e., 1080p fixed hdmi to 1024x768 monitor say)

item.title: UK developer creates £15 computer for kids
item.dc:creator: @sanga282 sanga282
item.description:
@sanga282 wrote:

[quote=“Moparisthebest, post:26, topic:394177”][quote author=Holic link=topic=491363.msg3595741#msg3595741 date=1305059932]

Do they really make HDMI to RCA adapters? If so, where at?

Also, you do realize you can hook a netbook up to any hdmi TV as well, right?

Nextag - Compare Prices Before You Buy

Rca to hdmi adapter | Cables | Compare Prices at Nextag

Rca to hdmi adapter - 130 results from brands RCA, Cables to Go, Startech, products like HDMI Male to 3 RCA Video Audio AV Cable Adapter For HDTV DVD 1080P US Seller LOT, iSimple ISHD01 MediaLinx HDMI to Composite Audio/Video, Roland V-1HD HD Video...

also, cheaper models of netbooks tend not to have hdmi. i have an aspire one and it doesnt do hdmi
[/quote]
Most HDMI TVs also have VGA inputs too.

This looks like it could work:

DinoDirect

Anpu HDMI to VGA and 3 RCA Audio Video AV Adapter Cable 5ft - DinoDirect.com

Shop anpu hdmi to vga and 3 rca audio video av adapter cable 5ft free shipping online at DinoDirect store.


can that be bi-directional? just out of curiosity, i thought you wouldnt be able to go VGA nad 3 RCA to HDMI but i could be wrong

Read full topic

item.title: UK developer creates £15 computer for kids
item.dc:creator: @moparisthebest Moparisthebest
item.description:
@moparisthebest wrote:

Niall:

[quote author=Moparisthebest link=topic=491363.msg3593715#msg3593715 date=1304871531]Anyway, back to the ‘computer’. Wow a cheap computer that requires a super-expensive TV to work with, this guy is a genius!.. He needs RCA Audio/video output, or coaxial output to make this truly a cheap, affordable computer.

lets be clear, it’s £15 or $22 for the pc, you can get hdmi to rca/whatever cables for £10 and even with a cheap HDMI tv it isn’t much more than the cheapest netbooks available, and it is MUCH better value imo(19" hdmi tv + pc vs 12.1" netbook? tv every time)[/quote]
Do they really make HDMI to RCA adapters? If so, where at?

Also, you do realize you can hook a netbook up to any hdmi TV as well, right?

Read full topic
item.source: UK developer creates £15 computer for kids

item.title: UK developer creates £15 computer for kids
item.dc:creator: @The_Un-Named The Un-Named
item.description:
@The_Un-Named wrote:

Moparisthebest:

Anyway, back to the ‘computer’. Wow a cheap computer that requires a super-expensive TV to work with, this guy is a genius!.. He needs RCA Audio/video output, or coaxial output to make this truly a cheap, affordable computer.

lets be clear, it’s £15 or $22 for the pc, you can get hdmi to rca/whatever cables for £10 and even with a cheap HDMI tv it isn’t much more than the cheapest netbooks available, and it is MUCH better value imo(19" hdmi tv + pc vs 12.1" netbook? tv every time)

I think the biggest plus side is, instead of schools buying much more expensive laptops or pcs(even in bulk and with discounts) all they will need now is the hdmi monitos, keyboards and mice, they can give the £15 computers away free and won’t spend much more than they already are and the students get a free pc

Read full topic

He says half the price of the TV and Computer. So £55 - £60!
[/quote]

Yes, I’m sorry, I multiplied twice instead of once to convert it to $, so you can get a nice netbook for the same price as that TV alone. No ‘cheap stick computer’ required. Thanks to Ollie and Sanga for proving my point for me.[/quote]

No you can’t get a nice netbook, you can get an awful netbook with the same specs as this thing but with a shittier screen

item.source: UK developer creates £15 computer for kids

item.title: UK developer creates £15 computer for kids
item.dc:creator: @tL tL
item.description:
@tL wrote:

[quote=“chri5, post:7, topic:394177”][quote author=tL link=topic=491363.msg3593736#msg3593736 date=1304872995]
It is created with HDMI due to how many people have HDMI capable TVs or monitors already, and for size. HDTV adoption in the UK is quite high.

And of course for size.
[/quote]
Surely if you’ve got the money for an HDTV you’ce got the money for a decent computer?[/quote]

That isn’t the point of it though. This is still aimed at people with ‘decent’ computers, it is aimed at kids that are learning the subject at school that want something to mess around with, to learn to program for such a device with a small amount of resources and experiment with different software.

Many kids don’t have their own computer, and due to their lack of knowledge of the subject aren’t confident with tinkering with their computers in fear of doing damage they’re not capable of fixing themselves.

This isn’t supposed to be a consumer device, it is an educational tool.

Read full topic
item.source: UK developer creates £15 computer for kids
